Introduction
Title: Introduction to Markov decision processes
Markov decision processes (MDPs) are a class of discrete-time stochastic control processes with a very special structure that makes them amenable to simple analysis. Despite this special structure they have many applications, for example in reinforcement learning. We will start with carefully defining the Markov decision process and then prove two intuitive results ‚Äî one of them by Blackwell (1964). Time permitting, we end with a brief discussion on connections with reinforcement learning.
Title: Basic results in Markov decision processes
We continue with our discussion from last time where we defined the Markov decision processes. We start with defining the notions of optimality and then discuss results when a policy is optimal.
Markov Decision Process
Markov decision processes (MDPs) are a class of discrete-time stochastic control processes with a very special structure that makes them amenable to simple analysis. Despite this special structure they have many applications, for example in reinforcement learning. This blog post isn‚Äôt about the applications though, but rather about the more technical existence and uniqueness questions ‚Äî questions which are often ignored. We will start with carefully defining the Markov decision process and then show two intuitive results. We end with a brief discussion on connections with reinforcement learning.
In a Markov decision process there is an underlying discrete-time Markov process whose trajectory can be influenced by a decision maker by choosing actions from a pre-specified class of admissible actions. The goal is choose actions in such a way so as to optimize a performance criterion. The state of the system at time n+1n+1n+1Ôªø then depends, in a Markovian way, on the state of the system and the action chosen at time n.n.n.Ôªø Depending on how general the state spaces and action space are, this framework can model a wide variety of interesting problems.
Consider an inventory control problem. You are the manager of a distribution centre who sells the product to shops and buys the product in bulk from a factory. Suppose the maximum capacity of the distribution centre is CCCÔªø units, and therefore the state space is S=[0,C]S = [0, C]S=[0,C]Ôªø. The state of the distribution centre at time nnnÔªø is xnx_nxn‚ÄãÔªø taking values in SSSÔªø. The action that you can take is order some quantity of product from the factory. The action space AAAÔªø also equals [0,C][0,C][0,C]Ôªø. At time nnnÔªø you order ana_nan‚ÄãÔªø from the factory. Of course, ana_nan‚ÄãÔªø must take values in [0,xn][0, x_n][0,xn‚Äã]Ôªø. The demand from the shops is given by the i.i.d. random variables {Œæn}n‚â•0\{\xi_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Œæn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø with common distribution Œº.\mu.Œº.Ôªø It costs hhhÔªø dollars per unit of product to hold the product, bbbÔªø dollars per unit of product to buy the product, and earns sssÔªø dollars per unit of product to sell the product. Any unmet demand is simply lost revenue. How should you choose a policy œÄ={an}\pi = \{a_n\}œÄ={an‚Äã}Ôªø to maximize the revenue over, say, NNNÔªø days?
Let us write the model more precisely. Suppose on day 000Ôªø you start with x0x_0x0‚ÄãÔªø units of product. Then we have
xn+1=max‚Å°{0,xn+an‚àíŒæn}=:f(xn,an,Œæn),n‚â•0.x_{n+1} = \max\{0, x_{n}+a_{n}-\xi_{n}\} =: f(x_{n}, a_{n}, \xi_{n}), \quad n \ge 0.xn+1‚Äã=max{0,xn‚Äã+an‚Äã‚àíŒæn‚Äã}=:f(xn‚Äã,an‚Äã,Œæn‚Äã),n‚â•0.
The revenue on day nnnÔªø is
rn=smin‚Å°{Œæn,xn}‚àíban‚àíhxn,n‚ààN.r_n = s \min\{\xi_n, x_n\} - b a_n - h x_n, \quad n \in \N.rn‚Äã=smin{Œæn‚Äã,xn‚Äã}‚àíban‚Äã‚àíhxn‚Äã,n‚ààN.
The total expected revenue is
JN(œÄ,x0)=E[‚àën=1Nrn].J_N(\pi, x_0) = \mathbb E \left[ \sum_{n=1}^N r_n \right].JN‚Äã(œÄ,x0‚Äã)=E[n=1‚àëN‚Äãrn‚Äã].
Does there exist an admissible policy œÄ‚àó\pi^*œÄ‚àóÔªø such that it maximises the total expected revenue? That is,
JN(œÄ‚àó,x0)=sup‚Å°œÄJN(œÄ,x0).J_N(\pi^*, x_0) = \sup_{\pi} J_N(\pi, x_0).JN‚Äã(œÄ‚àó,x0‚Äã)=œÄsup‚ÄãJN‚Äã(œÄ,x0‚Äã).
Is œÄ‚àó\pi^*œÄ‚àóÔªø optimal for every starting state x0x_0x0‚ÄãÔªø? It will be more convenient to model the transition dynamics of such a model using stochastic kernels, which informally model the transition probabilities of the process. That is, we want to find a stochastic kernel Œ∫\kappaŒ∫Ôªø from S√óAS \times AS√óAÔªø to SSSÔªø which gives the probability of the state at day nnnÔªø being in B‚äÇSB \subset SB‚äÇSÔªø given that on day n‚àí1n-1n‚àí1Ôªø the state was x=xn‚àí1x=x_{n-1}x=xn‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø and we took action a=an‚àí1a=a_{n-1}a=an‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø. We can do this as follows
Œ∫((x,a),B)=Œº({s‚ààS‚à£f(x,a,s)‚ààB}).\kappa((x,a), B) = \mu(\{s \in S \mid f(x,a,s) \in B\}).Œ∫((x,a),B)=Œº({s‚ààS‚à£f(x,a,s)‚ààB}).
We haven‚Äôt been precise about our formulation. To this end, let us start by defining the objects like stochastic kernels and sets which will define our action and state spaces.
Setting the Stage
Stochastic Kernels
Suppose that a particle is moving randomly in a state space given by a measurable space (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø. We would like to be able to know the probability, denoted with say Œ∫(x,B)\kappa(x, B)Œ∫(x,B)Ôªø, of the particle finding itself in a set B‚ààSB \in \mathscr{S}B‚ààSÔªø given that it started at state x‚ààS.x \in \mathcal S.x‚ààS.Ôªø Stochastic kernels model this notion of transition probabilities in a natural manner and we will rely heavily on them in our discussion.
Definition 1: Let (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø be two measurable spaces. A map
Œ∫‚Äâ‚Å£:S√óT‚Üí[0,1]\begin{equation*} \kappa \colon \mathcal S \times \mathscr{T} \to [0,1] \end{equation*}Œ∫:S√óT‚Üí[0,1]‚Äã
is called a stochastic kernel or a Markov kernel from (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø to (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø ‚Äî or, briefly, from S\mathcal SSÔªø to T\mathcal TTÔªø ‚Äî if
x‚Ü¶Œ∫(x,B)x \mapsto \kappa(x, B)x‚Ü¶Œ∫(x,B)Ôªø is S‚àí\mathscr{S}-S‚àíÔªømeasurable for each B‚ààTB \in \mathscr{T}B‚ààTÔªø, and
B‚Ü¶Œ∫(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B‚Ü¶Œ∫(x,B)Ôªø is a probability measure on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø for each x‚ààS.x \in \mathcal S.x‚ààS.Ôªø
If (T,T)=(S,S)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T}) = (\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(T,T)=(S,S)Ôªø, one simply says a kernel on (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø or on S\mathcal SSÔªø. One can view the stochastic kernel Œ∫\kappaŒ∫Ôªø as a measurable function from S\mathcal SSÔªø to the space P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal T)P(T)Ôªø of probability measures on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø, where the œÉ‚àí\sigma-œÉ‚àíÔªøalgebra on P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal T)P(T)Ôªø is generated by all the integration maps Œº‚Ü¶‚à´Sf‚ÄâdŒº\mu \mapsto \int_S f \, \mathrm{d}\muŒº‚Ü¶‚à´S‚ÄãfdŒºÔªø for all measurable f‚â•0f \ge 0f‚â•0Ôªø. For this reason, stochastic kernel are also called random probability measures. One can also view the stochastic kernel Œ∫\kappaŒ∫Ôªø as a probabilistic generalization of the concept of function from S\mathcal SSÔªø to T\mathcal TTÔªø: instead of associating with each x‚ààSx \in \mathcal Sx‚ààSÔªø a specific value from T\mathcal TTÔªø, one associates a probability distribution on T.\mathcal T.T.Ôªø
Examples

Given two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø and a measure Œº\muŒºÔªø on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø, the function

Regular Conditional Distribution

On this note we discuss disintegrations, which will simplify our notation and proofs involving regular conditional distributions.
Disintegration
We discuss the notion of disintegration in a general setting first.
Definition: Let (S,S,Œª)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S}, \lambda)(S,S,Œª)Ôªø be a measure space, with Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø being a œÉ\sigmaœÉÔªø-finite measure. Let (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr T)(T,T)Ôªø be a measurable space, and T‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚ÜíTT \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal TT:S‚ÜíTÔªø a measurable map. Finally, let Œº\muŒºÔªø be a œÉ\sigmaœÉÔªø-finite measure on T.\mathscr{T}.T.Ôªø We say that Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø has a disintegration {Œªt}t‚ààT\{\lambda_t\}_{t \in \mathcal T}{Œªt‚Äã}t‚ààT‚ÄãÔªø with respect to TTTÔªø and Œº\muŒºÔªø, or a (T,Œº)(T, \mu)(T,Œº)Ôªø-disintegration, if for each nonnegative measurable function f‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚Üí[0,‚àû]f \colon \mathcal S \to [0, \infty]f:S‚Üí[0,‚àû]Ôªø,
Œªt\lambda_tŒªt‚ÄãÔªø is a œÉ\sigmaœÉÔªø-finite measure on S\mathscr{S}SÔªø concentrated on {T=t}‚â°T‚àí1(t)\{T = t\} \equiv T^{-1}(t){T=t}‚â°T‚àí1(t)Ôªø, i.e., Œªt{T‚â†t}=0\lambda_t\{T \neq t\} = 0Œªt‚Äã{TÓÄ†=t}=0Ôªø, for Œº\muŒºÔªø-a.e. t‚ààTt \in \mathcal Tt‚ààTÔªø;
t‚Ü¶‚à´Sf‚ÄâdŒªtt \mapsto \int_{\mathcal S} f \,\mathrm{d}\lambda_tt‚Ü¶‚à´S‚ÄãfdŒªt‚ÄãÔªø is measurable; and
we have disintegration of the form

When does such a structure exist? The next theorem says for the cases we will consider ahead, disintegrations exist.

Borel Space
Very few meaningful statements can be made about Markov decision processes when we impose no regularity structure on the spaces involved and let them be any measurable spaces. This is where Borel spaces come in ‚Äî powerful results can be concluded with this structure, and yet they are sufficiently general to be satisfying.
Polish Space
Definition 2: A Polish space is a separable, completely metrizable topological space.
Examples
Any countable set with the discrete topology is Polish. So, for example, {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}Ôªø, N\NNÔªø and Z\ZZÔªø are Polish.
Rn\R^nRnÔªø with the usual topology is Polish, for each n‚ààN.n \in \N.n‚ààN.Ôªø
Any closed subspace of a Polish space is Polish.
The disjoint union of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
The product of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
All of these examples follow from elementary properties of metric spaces. So, for example, to show example 5, first show that the product of countably many separable metric spaces is itself separable using the definition of product topology, and then show that the product of countably many complete metric spaces is itself a complete metric space using the idea of the product metric and definition of Cauchy sequences.
Polish spaces are the probabilist‚Äôs favourite spaces to work with since a lot of spaces are Polish, while almost all results that hold in R\RRÔªø still hold in a Polish space. For example, if (X,dX)(X,d_X)(X,dX‚Äã)Ôªø is a compact metric space and (Y,dY)(Y, d_Y)(Y,dY‚Äã)Ôªø is Polish, then C(X,Y)C(X,Y)C(X,Y)Ôªø, the set of continuous functions from XXXÔªø to YYYÔªø with the uniform metric d(f,g)=sup‚Å°x‚ààXdY(f(x),g(y))d(f,g) = \sup_{x \in X} d_Y(f(x), g(y))d(f,g)=supx‚ààX‚ÄãdY‚Äã(f(x),g(y))Ôªø, is Polish.
Borel Isomorphism
Recall the notion of isomorphism between algebraic objects or the notion of homeomorphism between topological spaces. Both these notions give a bijective correspondence between two objects that preserves the algebraic or the topological structure. In a similar spirit we have the notion of isomorphism between two measurable spaces.
Definition 3 [Isomorphism and Borel isomorphism]: Two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)Ôªø and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)Ôªø are called isomorphic iff there is a bijective function f‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚ÜíTf \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Tf:S‚ÜíTÔªø such that both fffÔªø and its inverse f‚àí1f^{-1}f‚àí1Ôªø are measurable. The function fffÔªø is called an isomorphism. In the special case where S\mathcal SSÔªø and T\mathcal TTÔªø are metrizable spaces equipped with their Borel œÉ‚àí\sigma-œÉ‚àíÔªøalgebras and f‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚ÜíTf \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Tf:S‚ÜíTÔªø is an isomorphism, fffÔªø is called a Borel isomorphism, and S\mathcal SSÔªø and T\mathcal TTÔªø are called Borel isomorphic.
It is obvious from the definition that two countable metrizable spaces are Borel isomorphic if and only if they are of the same cardinality. For the uncountable case, it is not immediately obvious when two spaces are Borel isomorphic.
Definition 4 [Borel space]: A Borel space is a measurable space isomorphic to a Borel subset of a Polish space.
Proposition 1: Let S\mathcal SSÔªø be a metrizable topological space. Then S\mathcal SSÔªø is a Borel space if and only if S\mathcal SSÔªø is homeomorphic to a Borel subset of a Polish space.
Proposition 2: Two Borel spaces are Borel isomorphic if and only if they are of the same cardinality.
Proposition 3: For every infinite Borel subset S\mathcal SSÔªø of a Polish space, the cardinality of its Borel œÉ‚àí\sigma-œÉ‚àíÔªøalgebra B(S)\mathcal{B}(\mathcal S)B(S)Ôªø is c.\mathfrak{c}.c.Ôªø
Proposition 4: A Borel subset of a Borel space is itself a Borel space.
Borel space vs standard Borel space. Is a Borel space always a Borel subset of a Polish space?
Examples
Every Polish space is a Borel space.
Let P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal S)P(S)Ôªø be the space of probability measures on a Borel space S.\mathcal S.S.Ôªø If P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal S)P(S)Ôªø is endowed with the topology of weak convergence, then it is a Borel space. This fact becomes useful when dealing with partially observable MDPs. Here a standard approach is to transform them into an equivalent ‚Äúcompletely observable‚Äù MDP (the one in Definition 5 ahead) with a larger state space, a space of probability measures.
We will dealing with Borel spaces ahead, and therefore if no œÉ‚àí\sigma-œÉ‚àíÔªøalgebras are explicitly specified assume that we endow the spaces with their Borel œÉ‚àí\sigma-œÉ‚àíÔªøalgebras.
Markov Decision Process
Markov Decision Model

Our model evolves through time such that we can observe the state of the model and take admissible actions at discrete times n=0,1,2,‚Ä¶.n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots.n=0,1,2,‚Ä¶.Ôªø We will say n‚â•0n \ge 0n‚â•0Ôªø to mean nnnÔªø is a non-negative integer.

Policy
A policy œÄ={œÄn}n‚â•0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}œÄ={œÄn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø is a sequence of prescriptions œÄn\pi_nœÄn‚ÄãÔªø that at time nnnÔªø gives a rule for selecting the action. œÄn\pi_nœÄn‚ÄãÔªø can be a randomized procedure or a deterministic procedure; it can depend on the entire history of the model or only on the current state. Let us formalize this concept.
History
Definition 6: For each time n‚â•0n \ge 0n‚â•0Ôªø, define the space Hn\mathcal H_nHn‚ÄãÔªø of admissible histories up to time nnnÔªø by H0=S\mathcal H_0 = \mathcal SH0‚Äã=SÔªø, and

Definition 7: A policy œÄ={œÄn}n‚â•0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}œÄ={œÄn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø is a sequence of stochastic kernels œÄn\pi_nœÄn‚ÄãÔªø from Hn\mathcal H_nHn‚ÄãÔªø to A\mathcal AAÔªø subject to the constraint

Classes of Policies
The largest class of policies we consider is Œ†\PiŒ†Ôªø defined above. If instead of using the entire history, the policy makes a decision using only the current state, then we get a Markov policy.
Definition 8: If a policy œÄ={œÄn}n‚â•0‚ààŒ†\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \PiœÄ={œÄn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚Äã‚ààŒ†Ôªø is such that for each n‚â•0n \ge 0n‚â•0Ôªø, there exists a stochastic kernel œÜn\varphi_nœÜn‚ÄãÔªø from S\mathcal SSÔªø to A\mathcal AAÔªø such that
œÄn(hn,‚ãÖ)=œÜn(xn,‚ãÖ),‚àÄ‚ÄÖ‚Äähn=(x0,a0,‚Ä¶,xn‚àí1,an‚àí1,xn)‚ààHn,\pi_n(h_n, \cdot) = \varphi_n(x_n, \cdot), \quad \forall \; h_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathcal H_n,œÄn‚Äã(hn‚Äã,‚ãÖ)=œÜn‚Äã(xn‚Äã,‚ãÖ),‚àÄhn‚Äã=(x0‚Äã,a0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚àí1‚Äã,an‚àí1‚Äã,xn‚Äã)‚ààHn‚Äã,
then œÄ\piœÄÔªø is called a Markov policy. We denote the set of all Markov policies by Œ†M.\Pi_M.Œ†M‚Äã.Ôªø
Even more simply, if our policy at each time doesn‚Äôt depend on the time but only on the current state, we get a stationary policy. A stationary policy is necessarily Markovian.
Definition 9: If a policy œÄ={œÄn}n‚â•0‚ààŒ†\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \PiœÄ={œÄn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚Äã‚ààŒ†Ôªø is such that there exists a stochastic kernel œÜ\varphiœÜÔªø from S\mathcal SSÔªø to A\mathcal AAÔªø such that for each n‚â•0n \ge 0n‚â•0Ôªø,

then œÄ\piœÄÔªø is called a stationary policy. We denote the set of all stationary policies by Œ†S.\Pi_S.Œ†S‚Äã.Ôªø
What about deterministic policies?

The set Œ†\PiŒ†Ôªø contains these deterministic policies, as can be easily seen by observing that for the deterministic policy f={fn}n‚â•0f = \{f_n\}_{n \ge 0}f={fn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø the corresponding policy œÄ={œÄn}n‚â•0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}œÄ={œÄn‚Äã}n‚â•0‚ÄãÔªø is given by

Canonical Construction
A natural questions now arises:
‚ùì

The answer to our question is, of course, yes. At this point recall the Ionescu-Tulcea theorem:

Markov Property
Although equation (C3) looks like a Markov condition, the process {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn‚Äã}Ôªø may not be a Markov process because of the dependence on history through the action process. It seems intuitively plausible that if the policy is Markov, then the state process should also be Markov. We prove this now.
Notation: If œÜ\varphiœÜÔªø is a stochastic kernel from S\mathcal SSÔªø to A\mathcal AAÔªø, then for every x‚ààSx \in \mathcal Sx‚ààSÔªø,

Performance Criteria
We haven‚Äôt even defined what performance criterion we are optimizing for! Suppose we have the Markov decision process and a class Œ†A\Pi_AŒ†A‚ÄãÔªø of admissible policies, where Œ†A\Pi_AŒ†A‚ÄãÔªø could be Œ†\PiŒ†Ôªø or Œ†DM\Pi_{DM}Œ†DM‚ÄãÔªø or any other class we discussed above. The performance criterion measures how ‚Äúgood‚Äù a policy is. There are two performance criteria which are common in the literature: expected total reward and the long-run average expected reward per unit time.
Expected Total Reward
Definition 13: Given an initial state x0=x‚ààSx_0 = x \in \mathcal Sx0‚Äã=x‚ààSÔªø, a policy œÄ‚ààŒ†A\pi \in \Pi_AœÄ‚ààŒ†A‚ÄãÔªø, and a discount factor Œ≤‚àà(0,1)\beta \in (0,1)Œ≤‚àà(0,1)Ôªø, the expected total reward is given by
J(œÄ,x):=ExœÄ[‚àën=0‚àûŒ≤nr(Xn,An,Xn+1)].J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^\infty \beta^n r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) \right].J(œÄ,x):=ExœÄ‚Äã[n=0‚àë‚àû‚ÄãŒ≤nr(Xn‚Äã,An‚Äã,Xn+1‚Äã)].
Recall that ExœÄ\mathbb{E}_x^\piExœÄ‚ÄãÔªø simply means EŒ¥xœÄ.\mathbb{E}_{\delta_x}^\pi.EŒ¥x‚ÄãœÄ‚Äã.Ôªø In this setting it is usually assumed that the reward function rrrÔªø is bounded, so that J(œÄ,x)J(\pi, x)J(œÄ,x)Ôªø is a bounded function. In this blog post we will be interested in finite horizon problem, i.e., there is a finite N‚ààNN \in \NN‚ààNÔªø such that the performance criterion is
J(œÄ,x):=ExœÄ[‚àën=0N‚àí1r(Xn,An,Xn+1)+rN(XN)],J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) + r_N(X_N) \right],J(œÄ,x):=ExœÄ‚Äã[n=0‚àëN‚àí1‚Äãr(Xn‚Äã,An‚Äã,Xn+1‚Äã)+rN‚Äã(XN‚Äã)],
with rN‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚Üí[‚àí‚àû,‚àû)r_N \colon \mathcal S \to [-\infty, \infty)rN‚Äã:S‚Üí[‚àí‚àû,‚àû)Ôªø, a measurable function, denoting the terminal reward. We use J‚àóJ^*J‚àóÔªø to denote the value function
J‚àó(x):=sup‚Å°œÄ‚ààŒ†AJ(œÄ,x),x‚ààS.J^*(x) := \sup_{\pi \in \Pi_A} J(\pi, x), \quad x \in \mathcal S.J‚àó(x):=œÄ‚ààŒ†A‚Äãsup‚ÄãJ(œÄ,x),x‚ààS.
The problem is to find (if it exists!) a policy œÄ‚àó‚ààŒ†A\pi^* \in \Pi_AœÄ‚àó‚ààŒ†A‚ÄãÔªø such that
J(œÄ‚àó,x)=J‚àó(x),‚àÄ‚ÄÖ‚Ääx‚ààS.J(\pi^*, x) = J^*(x), \quad \forall \; x \in \mathcal S.J(œÄ‚àó,x)=J‚àó(x),‚àÄx‚ààS.
Note that in this setting, because of the expectation, we can replace the reward function rrrÔªø by r‚Äæ\overline rrÔªø:
r‚Äæn(x,a)=‚à´Sn+1r((x,a),y)Œ∫((x,a),dy).\overline r_n(x,a) = \int_{\mathcal S_{n+1}} r((x,a),y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y).rn‚Äã(x,a)=‚à´Sn+1‚Äã‚Äãr((x,a),y)Œ∫((x,a),dy).
Therefore, we will now just assume that the reward function rrrÔªø is of the form
r‚Äâ‚Å£:‚ü¶Œ±‚üß‚Üí[‚àí‚àû,‚àû).r \colon \llbracket\alpha\rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty).r:[[Œ±]]‚Üí[‚àí‚àû,‚àû).
Long-run Average Expected Reward
Definition 14: Given an initial state x0=x‚ààSx_0 = x \in \mathcal Sx0‚Äã=x‚ààSÔªø and a policy œÄ‚ààŒ†A\pi \in \Pi_AœÄ‚ààŒ†A‚ÄãÔªø, the long-run average expected reward per unit time is given by
J(œÄ,x):=lim‚Äâinf‚Å°m‚Üí‚àû1mExœÄ[‚àën=0mr(Xn,An,Xn+1)].J(\pi, x) := \liminf_{m \to \infty} \frac{1}{m} \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^m r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) \right].J(œÄ,x):=m‚Üí‚àûliminf‚Äãm1‚ÄãExœÄ‚Äã[n=0‚àëm‚Äãr(Xn‚Äã,An‚Äã,Xn+1‚Äã)].
We could have taken lim‚Äâsup‚Å°\limsuplimsupÔªø, and both give different results, but the lim‚Äâinf‚Å°\liminfliminfÔªø case is easier to handle. Intuitively, the lim‚Äâinf‚Å°\liminfliminfÔªø case gives a more pessimistic picture, while the lim‚Äâsup‚Å°\limsuplimsupÔªø gives a more optimistic picture.
Optimal Policy
Deterministic Markov Policy 1
Suppose that we are in the finite horizon with the expected total reward regime. Assume that the terminal reward is 000Ôªø for simplicity, and that the
reward¬†function¬†r‚Äâ‚Å£:S√óA‚ÜíR¬†is¬†bounded.(A4)\text{reward function } r \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \to \R \text{ is bounded.} \tag{A4}reward¬†function¬†r:S√óA‚ÜíR¬†is¬†bounded.(A4)
As the notation suggests, we have also implicitly assumed that Œ±(x)=A\alpha(x) = \mathcal AŒ±(x)=AÔªø for every x‚ààS.x \in \mathcal S.x‚ààS.Ôªø In this setting we want to compare the classes Œ†D\Pi_DŒ†D‚ÄãÔªø and Œ†DM\Pi_{DM}Œ†DM‚ÄãÔªø of policies. We claim that there is no loss of optimality in restricting attention to the smaller class Œ†DM\Pi_{DM}Œ†DM‚ÄãÔªø of deterministic Markov policies. This is a surprising result! Policies in Œ†D\Pi_DŒ†D‚ÄãÔªø can depend on the entire history in a very complicated manner, and it is not clear why a deterministic Markov policy should be just as good. I came across this result in a blog post by Maxim Raginsky [6]. The key result which we will use is from a 1964 paper by David Blackwell [5]. We state this result without proof.
Theorem 3 [Blackwell]: Let S,T,\mathcal S,\mathcal T,S,T,Ôªø and A\mathcal AAÔªø be Borel spaces, let Q\mathbb QQÔªø be any probability measure on the product space S√óT\mathcal S \times \mathcal TS√óTÔªø, and let R‚Äâ‚Å£:S√óA‚ÜíRR \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \to \RR:S√óA‚ÜíRÔªø be a bounded measurable reward function. Then for any measurable function g‚Äâ‚Å£:S√óT‚ÜíAg \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal T \to \mathcal Ag:S√óT‚ÜíAÔªø there exists another measurable function f‚Äâ‚Å£:S‚ÜíAf \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Af:S‚ÜíAÔªø such that
‚à´S√óTR(x,f(x))‚ÄâQ(dx,dy)‚â•‚à´S√óTR(x,g(x,y))‚ÄâQ(dx,dy).\int_{\mathcal S \times \mathcal T} R(x, f(x)) \, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y) \ge \int_{\mathcal S \times \mathcal T} R(x, g(x,y))\, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y).‚à´S√óT‚ÄãR(x,f(x))Q(dx,dy)‚â•‚à´S√óT‚ÄãR(x,g(x,y))Q(dx,dy).
Let us now state and prove our theorem. Instead of fixing an initial state xxxÔªø as above in the total expected reward function, we let the initial distribution be any probability measure ŒΩ.\nu.ŒΩ.Ôªø
Theorem 4: For any policy œÄ‚ààŒ†D\pi \in \Pi_DœÄ‚ààŒ†D‚ÄãÔªø, there exists a policy œÑ‚ààŒ†DM\tau \in \Pi_{DM}œÑ‚ààŒ†DM‚ÄãÔªø such that J(œÑ)‚â•J(œÄ).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(œÑ)‚â•J(œÄ).Ôªø
Here, J(œÄ)J(\pi)J(œÄ)Ôªø, of course, denotes

Before we prove the theorem, let us establish two lemmas.

The next lemma states that when N=3N=3N=3Ôªø and the last policy œÄ2\pi_2œÄ2‚ÄãÔªø is Markov, then we can choose even the second policy to be Markov. More precisely,

Proof of Theorem 4:

Deterministic Markov Policy 2
When can we say that there exists an optimal policy which is a deterministic Markov policy? Making some assumptions with regards to measurable selections, we can find, using dynamic programming, the optimal policy.
Theorem 5: Define the real-valued functions JN,JN‚àí1,‚Ä¶,J0J_N, J_{N-1}, \ldots, J_0JN‚Äã,JN‚àí1‚Äã,‚Ä¶,J0‚ÄãÔªø on S\mathcal SSÔªø inductively as follows: for each x‚ààSx \in \mathcal Sx‚ààSÔªø,

Proof:

This proves the first claim in (5) for all n=0,‚Ä¶,N.n = 0, \ldots, N.n=0,‚Ä¶,N.Ôªø Proceeding in a similar manner for œÄ=œÄ‚àó\pi = \pi^*œÄ=œÄ‚àóÔªø, where the first inequality in (6) becomes an equality by the induction hypothesis, and the second inequality in (6) becomes an equality by the structure of œÄ‚àó\pi^*œÄ‚àóÔªø, we conclude the second claim in (5) also. ‚ñ°\square‚ñ°Ôªø

Reinforcement Learning
In RL, the transition law Œ∫\kappaŒ∫Ôªø and the reward function rrrÔªø are unknown, and must be ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù by appropriate exploration. This induces the exploration/exploitation dilemma.
The reward function may be zero for all n=0,‚Ä¶,N‚àí1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,‚Ä¶,N‚àí1Ôªø, and only the terminal cost might be giving us feedback. This sharpens the credit assignment problem.
The state may also not be directly observable, and thus a filtering problem gets added on top.
